children.subject: This is what is says: Just want to be extra careful since I've heard that sometimes this isn't accurate
I was told today by an adviser and told by two other advisers that this tool is completely accurate and is what "graduates you."
Doesn't the 1/3 P/NP calculator lets you manually insert the number of P/NP units and it will tell you the ratio?

history.content:
Here's another way to look at it. 

120 required units - 61 transfer units = 59 units

67% of 59 units = # of letter graded units you must have

Therefore, you must have 40 letter graded units in order to meet the 1/3 rule.

Keep in mind that in order to be eligible for honors at graduation, you must have 43 UC letter graded units.

If you keep your 7 units graded for F20, it appears that you will have 43 UC letter graded units.

Hi, I've been scrolling through numerous Piazza posts and asked my advisors for help with 1/3 PNP requirement, but I am still very confused. I would appreciate if someone could help me check my math and ensure everything is accurate since grading deadline is today. Thank you!

120 required units - 61 transfer units = 59 units (denominator)

Fall 2019: 20 units graded
Spring 2020: 16 units graded, 4 units PNP
Fall 2020: 7 units graded, 8 units PNP
Spring 2021: 15 units PNP

Since Spring 2020 PNP units don't count, this means I would have 20+16+7=43 graded units and 8+15 = 23 PNP units right?

Since the denominator is only 59 units, would the numerator be 59-43 = 16 or just simply 23 PNP units? If it's 16/59 then I'm under 1/3, but if it's 23/59, then I'm over. Very confused and would appreciate any help! Thank you!
history.subject: urgent 1/3 PNP requirement: please help!
